column2: Margaret disliked the prospect of the long walk through these streets, before she came to the fields which she had planned to reach.
column3: Margaret disliked the prospect of the long walk through these streets, before she came to the fields which she had planned to reach.

column2: Instead, she would go and see Bessy Higgins. It would not be so refreshing as a quiet country walk, but still it would perhaps be doing the kinder thing.
column3: Instead, she would go and see Bessy Higgins. It would not be so refreshing as a quiet country walk, but still it would perhaps be doing the kinder thing.

column2: Nicholas Higgins was sitting by the fire smoking, as she went in. Bessy was rocking herself on the other side.
column3: Nicholas Higgins was sitting by the fire smoking, as she went in. Bessy was rocking herself on the other side.

column2: Nicholas took the pipe out of his mouth, and standing up, pushed his chair towards Margaret;
column3: Nicholas took the pipe out of his mouth, and standing up, pushed his chair towards Margaret;

column2: he leant against the chimney piece in a lounging attitude, while she asked Bessy how she was.
column3: he leant against the chimney piece in a lounging attitude, while she asked Bessy how she was.

column2: Hoos rather down i the mouth in regard to spirits, but hoos better in health. Hoo doesnt like this strike. Hoos a deal too much set on peace and quietness at any price.
column3: Hoos rather down i the mouth in regard to spirits, but hoos better in health. Hoo doesnt like this strike. Hoos a deal too much set on peace and quietness at any price.

column2: This is the third strike Ive seen, said she, sighing, as if that was answer and explanation enough.
column3: This is the third strike Ive seen, said she, sighing, as if that was answer and explanation enough.

column2: Well, third time pays for all. See if we dont dang the masters this time.
column3: Well, third time pays for all. See if we dont dang the masters this time.

column2: See if they dont come, and beg us to come back at our own price. Thats all. Weve missed it afore time, I grant yo; but this time wen laid our plans desperate deep.
column3: See if they dont come, and beg us to come back at our own price. Thats all. Weve missed it afore time, I grant yo; but this time wen laid our plans desperate deep.

column2: Why do you strike? asked Margaret. Striking is leaving off work till you get your own rate of wages, is it not?
column3: Why do you strike? asked Margaret. Striking is leaving off work till you get your own rate of wages, is it not?

column2: You must not wonder at my ignorance; where I come from I never heard of a strike.
column3: You must not wonder at my ignorance; where I come from I never heard of a strike.

column2: I wish I were there, said Bessy, wearily. But its not for me to get sick and tired o strikes.
column3: I wish I were there, said Bessy, wearily. But its not for me to get sick and tired o strikes.

column2: This is the last Ill see. Before its ended I shall be in the Great City—the Holy Jerusalem.
column3: This is the last Ill see. Before its ended I shall be in the Great City-the Holy Jerusalem.

column2: Hoos so full of the life to come, hoo cannot think of the present.
column3: Hoos so full of the life to come, hoo cannot think of the present.

column2: Now I, yo see, am bound to do the best I can here. I think a bird i the hand is worth two i the bush. So thems the different views we take on the strike question.
column3: Now I, yo see, am bound to do the best I can here. I think a bird i the hand is worth two i the bush. So thems the different views we take on the strike question.

column2: But, said Margaret, if the people struck, as you call it, where I come from, as they are mostly all field labourers, the seed would not be sown, the hay got in, the corn reaped.
column3: But, said Margaret, if the people struck, as you call it, where I come from, as they are mostly all field labourers, the seed would not be sown, the hay got in, the corn reaped.

column2: Well? said he. He had resumed his pipe, and put his well in the form of an interrogation.
column3: Well? said he. He had resumed his pipe, and put his well in the form of an interrogation.

column2: Why, she went on, what would become of the farmers.
column3: Why, she went on, what would become of the farmers.

column2: He puffed away. I reckon theyd have either to give up their farms, or to give fair rate of wage.
column3: He puffed away. I reckon theyd have either to give up their farms, or to give fair rate of wage.

column2: Suppose they could not, or would not do the last; they could not give up their farms all in a minute, however much they might wish to do so;
column3: Suppose they could not, or would not do the last; they could not give up their farms all in a minute, however much they might wish to do so;

column2: but they would have no hay, nor corn to sell that year; and where would the money come from to pay the labourers wages the next?
column3: but they would have no hay, nor corn to sell that year; and where would the money come from to pay the labourers wages the next?

column2: Still puffing away. At last he said:
column3: Still puffing away. At last he said:

column2: I know nought of your ways down South. I have heerd theyre a pack of spiritless, down-trodden men;
column3: I know nought of your ways down South. I have heerd theyre a pack of spiritless, down-trodden men;

column2: welly clemmed to death; too much dazed wi clemming to know when theyre put upon.
column3: welly clemmed to death; too much dazed wi clemming to know when theyre put upon.

column2: Now, its not so here. We known when were put upon; and ween too much blood in us to stand it.
column3: Now, its not so here. We known when were put upon; and ween too much blood in us to stand it.

column2: We just take our hands fro our looms, and say, Yo may clem us, but yoll not put upon us, my masters! And be danged tothem, they shant this time!
column3: We just take our hands fro our looms, and say, Yo may clem us, but yoll not put upon us, my masters! And be danged tothem, they shant this time!

column2: I wish I lived down South, said Bessy.
column3: I wish I lived down South, said Bessy.

column2: Theres a deal to bear there, said Margaret. There are sorrows to bear everywhere. There is very hard bodily labour to be gone through, with very little food to give strength.
column3: Theres a deal to bear there, said Margaret. There are sorrows to bear everywhere. There is very hard bodily labour to be gone through, with very little food to give strength.

column2: But its out of doors, said Bessy. And away from the endless, endless noise, and sickening heat.
column3: But its out of doors, said Bessy. And away from the endless, endless noise, and sickening heat.

column2: Its sometimes in heavy rain, and sometimes in bitter cold.
column3: Its sometimes in heavy rain, and sometimes in bitter cold.

column2: A young person can stand it; but an old man gets racked with rheumatism, and bent and withered before his time; yet he must just work on the same, or else go to the workhouse.
column3: A young person can stand it; but an old man gets racked with rheumatism, and bent and withered before his time; yet he must just work on the same, or else go to the workhouse.

column2: I thought yo were so taken wi the ways of the South country.
column3: I thought yo were so taken wi the ways of the South country.

column2: So I am, said Margaret, smiling a little, as she found herself thus caught.
column3: So I am, said Margaret, smiling a little, as she found herself thus caught.

column2: I only mean, Bessy, theres good and bad in everything in this world; and as you felt the bad up here, I thought it was but fair you should know the bad down there.
column3: I only mean, Bessy, theres good and bad in everything in this world; and as you felt the bad up here, I thought it was but fair you should know the bad down there.

column2: And yo say they never strike down there? asked Nicholas, abruptly.
column3: And yo say they never strike down there? asked Nicholas, abruptly.

column2: No! said Margaret; I think they have too much sense.
column3: No! said Margaret; I think they have too much sense.

column2: An I think, replied he, dashing the ashes out of his pipe with so much vehemence that it broke, its not that theyve too much sense, but that theyve too little spirit.
column3: An I think, replied he, dashing the ashes out of his pipe with so much vehemence that it broke, its not that theyve too much sense, but that theyve too little spirit.

column2: O, father! said Bessy, what have ye gained by striking?
column3: O, father! said Bessy, what have ye gained by striking?

column2: Think of that first strike when mother died—how we all had to clem—you the worst of all;
column3: Think of that first strike when mother died-how we all had to clem-you the worst of all;

column2: and yet many a one went in every week at the same wage, till all were gone in that there was work for; and some went beggars all their lives at after.
column3: and yet many a one went in every week at the same wage, till all were gone in that there was work for; and some went beggars all their lives at after.

column2: Ay, said he. That there strike was badly managed. Folk got into the management of it, as were either fools or not true men. Yoll see, itll be different this time.
column3: Ay, said he. That there strike was badly managed. Folk got into the management of it, as were either fools or not true men. Yoll see, itll be different this time.

column2: But all this time youve not told me what youre striking for, said Margaret, again.
column3: But all this time youve not told me what youre striking for, said Margaret, again.

column2: Why, yo see, theres five or six masters who have set themselves again paying the wages theyve been paying these two years past, and flourishing upon, and getting richer upon.
column3: Why, yo see, theres five or six masters who have set themselves again paying the wages theyve been paying these two years past, and flourishing upon, and getting richer upon.

column2: And now they come to us, and say were to take less.
column3: And now they come to us, and say were to take less.

column2: And we wont. Well just clem them to death first; and see wholl work forthem then. Theyll have killed the goose that laidthem the golden eggs, I reckon.
column3: And we wont. Well just clem them to death first; and see wholl work forthem then. Theyll have killed the goose that laidthem the golden eggs, I reckon.

column2: And so you plan dying, in order to be revenged upon them!
column3: And so you plan dying, in order to be revenged upon them!

column2: No, said he, I dunnot. I just look forward to the chance of dying at my post sooner than yield.
column3: No, said he, I dunnot. I just look forward to the chance of dying at my post sooner than yield.

column2: Thats what folk call fine and honourable in a soldier, and why not in a poor weaver-chap?
column3: Thats what folk call fine and honourable in a soldier, and why not in a poor weaver-chap?

column2: But, said Margaret, a soldier dies in the cause of the Nation—in the cause of others.
column3: But, said Margaret, a soldier dies in the cause of the Nation-in the cause of others.

column2: He laughed grimly. My lass, said he, yore but a young wench, but dont yo think I can keep three people—thats Bessy, and Mary, and me—on sixteen shilling a week?
column3: He laughed grimly. My lass, said he, yore but a young wench, but dont yo think I can keep three people-thats Bessy, and Mary, and me-on sixteen shilling a week?

column2: Dun yo think its for mysel Im striking work at this time?
column3: Dun yo think its for mysel Im striking work at this time?

column2: Its just as much in the cause of others as yon soldier—only mappen, the cause he dies for is just that of somebody he never clapt eyes on,
column3: Its just as much in the cause of others as yon soldier-only mappen, the cause he dies for is just that of somebody he never clapt eyes on,

column2: nor heerd on all his born days, while I take up John Bouchers cause, as lives next door but one, wi a sickly wife, and eight childer, none onthem factory age;
column3: nor heerd on all his born days, while I take up John Bouchers cause, as lives next door but one, wi a sickly wife, and eight childer, none onthem factory age;

column2: and I dont take up his cause only, though hes a poor good-for-nought, as can only manage two looms at a time, but I take up the cause o justice.
column3: and I dont take up his cause only, though hes a poor good-for-nought, as can only manage two looms at a time, but I take up the cause o justice.

column2: Why are we to have less wage now, I ask, than two year ago?
column3: Why are we to have less wage now, I ask, than two year ago?

column2: Dont ask me, said Margaret; I am very ignorant. Ask some of your masters.
column3: Dont ask me, said Margaret; I am very ignorant. Ask some of your masters.

column2: Surely they will give you a reason for it. It is not merely an arbitrary decision of theirs, come to without reason.
column3: Surely they will give you a reason for it. It is not merely an arbitrary decision of theirs, come to without reason.

column2: Yore just a foreigner, and nothing more, said he, contemptuously.
column3: Yore just a foreigner, and nothing more, said he, contemptuously.

column2: Much yo know about it. Ask the masters! Theyd tell us to mind our own business, and theyd mind theirs.
column3: Much yo know about it. Ask the masters! Theyd tell us to mind our own business, and theyd mind theirs.

column2: Our business being, yo understand, to take the bated wage, and be thankful, and their business to bate us down to clemming point, to swell their profits. Thats what it is.
column3: Our business being, yo understand, to take the bated wage, and be thankful, and their business to bate us down to clemming point, to swell their profits. Thats what it is.

column2: But said Margaret, determined not to give way, although she saw she was irritating him, the state of trade may be such as not to enable them to give you the same remuneration.
column3: But said Margaret, determined not to give way, although she saw she was irritating him, the state of trade may be such as not to enable them to give you the same remuneration.

column2: State o trade! Thats just a piece o masters humbug.
column3: State o trade! Thats just a piece o masters humbug.

column2: Its rate o wages I was talking of. the masters keep the state o trade in their own hands;
column3: Its rate o wages I was talking of. the masters keep the state o trade in their own hands;

column2: and just walk it forward like a black bug-a-boo, to frighten naughty children with into being good.
column3: and just walk it forward like a black bug-a-boo, to frighten naughty children with into being good.

column2: Ill tell yo its their part,—their cue, as some folks call it,—to beat us down, to swell their fortunes;
column3: Ill tell yo its their part,-their cue, as some folks call it,-to beat us down, to swell their fortunes;

column2: and its ours to stand up and fight hard,—not for ourselves alone, but for them round about us—for justice and fair play.
column3: and its ours to stand up and fight hard,-not for ourselves alone, but for them round about us-for justice and fair play.

column2: We help to make their profits, and we ought to help spendthem.
column3: We help to make their profits, and we ought to help spendthem.

column2: Its not that we want their brass so much this time, as weve done many a time afore.
column3: Its not that we want their brass so much this time, as weve done many a time afore.

column2: Wen getten money laid by; and were resolved to stand and fall together; not a man on us will go in for less wage than the Union says is our due.
column3: Wen getten money laid by; and were resolved to stand and fall together; not a man on us will go in for less wage than the Union says is our due.

column2: So I say, hooray for the strike, and let Thornton, and Slickson, and Hamper, and their set look to it!
column3: So I say, hooray for the strike, and let Thornton, and Slickson, and Hamper, and their set look to it!

column2: Thornton! said Margaret. mister Thornton of Marlborough Street?
column3: Thornton! said Margaret. mister Thornton of Marlborough Street?

column2: Aye! Thornton o Marlborough Mill, as we call him.
column3: Aye! Thornton o Marlborough Mill, as we call him.

column2: He is one of the masters you are striving with, is he not? What sort of a master is he?
column3: He is one of the masters you are striving with, is he not? What sort of a master is he?

column2: Did yo ever see a bulldog? Set a bulldog on hind legs, and dress him up in coat and breeches, and yon just getten John Thornton.
column3: Did yo ever see a bulldog? Set a bulldog on hind legs, and dress him up in coat and breeches, and yon just getten John Thornton.

column2: Nay, said Margaret, laughing, I deny that. mister Thornton is plain enough, but hes not like a bulldog, with its short broad nose, and snarling upper lip.
column3: Nay, said Margaret, laughing, I deny that. mister Thornton is plain enough, but hes not like a bulldog, with its short broad nose, and snarling upper lip.

column2: No! not in look, I grant yo. But let John Thornton get hold on a notion, and hell stick to it like a bulldog; yo might pull him away wi a pitch-fork ere hed leave go.
column3: No! not in look, I grant yo. But let John Thornton get hold on a notion, and hell stick to it like a bulldog; yo might pull him away wi a pitch-fork ere hed leave go.

column2: Hes worth fighting wi, is John Thornton. As for Slickson, I take it, some o these days hell wheedle his men back wi fair promises;
column3: Hes worth fighting wi, is John Thornton. As for Slickson, I take it, some o these days hell wheedle his men back wi fair promises;

column2: that theyll just get cheated out of as soon as theyre in his power again.
column3: that theyll just get cheated out of as soon as theyre in his power again.

column2: Hell work his fines well out onthem, Ill warrant.
column3: Hell work his fines well out onthem, Ill warrant.

column2: Hes as slippery as an eel, he is. Hes like a cat,—as sleek, and cunning, and fierce.
column3: Hes as slippery as an eel, he is. Hes like a cat,-as sleek, and cunning, and fierce.

column2: Itll never be an honest up and down fight wi him, as it will be wi Thornton. Thorntons as dour as a door-nail; an obstinate chap, every inch on him,—th oud bulldog!
column3: Itll never be an honest up and down fight wi him, as it will be wi Thornton. Thorntons as dour as a door-nail; an obstinate chap, every inch on him,-th oud bulldog!

column2: Poor Bessy! said Margaret, turning round to her. You sigh over it all. You dont like struggling and fighting as your father does, do you?
column3: Poor Bessy! said Margaret, turning round to her. You sigh over it all. You dont like struggling and fighting as your father does, do you?

column2: No! said she, heavily. Im sick on it. I could have wished to have had other talk about me in my latter days,
column3: No! said she, heavily. Im sick on it. I could have wished to have had other talk about me in my latter days,

column2: than just the clashing and clanging and clattering that has wearied a my life long, about work and wages, and masters, and hands, and knobsticks.
column3: than just the clashing and clanging and clattering that has wearied a my life long, about work and wages, and masters, and hands, and knobsticks.

column2: Poor wench! latter days be farred! Thourt looking a sight better already for a little stir and change. Beside, I shall be a deal here to make it more lively for thee.
column3: Poor wench! latter days be farred! Thourt looking a sight better already for a little stir and change. Beside, I shall be a deal here to make it more lively for thee.

column2: Tobacco-smoke chokes me! said she, querulously.
column3: Tobacco-smoke chokes me! said she, querulously.

column2: Then Ill never smoke no more i the house! he replied, tenderly. But why didst thou not tell me afore, thou foolish wench?
column3: Then Ill never smoke no more i the house! he replied, tenderly. But why didst thou not tell me afore, thou foolish wench?

column2: She did not speak for a while, and then so low that only Margaret heard her:
column3: She did not speak for a while, and then so low that only Margaret heard her:

column2: I reckon, hell want a the comfort he can get out o either pipe or drink afore hes done.
column3: I reckon, hell want a the comfort he can get out o either pipe or drink afore hes done.

column2: Her father went out of doors, evidently to finish his pipe.
column3: Her father went out of doors, evidently to finish his pipe.

column2: Bessy said passionately,
column3: Bessy said passionately,

column2: Now am not I a fool,—am I not, Miss?—there, I knew I ought for to keep father at home, and away fro the folk that are always ready for to tempt a man,
column3: Now am not I a fool,-am I not, Miss?-there, I knew I ought for to keep father at home, and away fro the folk that are always ready for to tempt a man,

column2: in time o strike, to go drink,—and there my tongue must needs quarrel with this pipe o hisn,—and hell go off,
column3: in time o strike, to go drink,-and there my tongue must needs quarrel with this pipe o hisn,-and hell go off,

column2: I know he will,—as often as he wants to smoke—and nobody knows where itll end.
column3: I know he will,-as often as he wants to smoke-and nobody knows where itll end.

column2: I wish Id letten myself be choked first.
column3: I wish Id letten myself be choked first.

column2: But does your father drink? asked Margaret.
column3: But does your father drink? asked Margaret.

column2: No—not to say drink, replied she, still in the same wild excited tone.
column3: No-not to say drink, replied she, still in the same wild excited tone.

column2: But what win ye have? There are days wi you, as wi other folk, I suppose, when yo get up and go through the hours,
column3: But what win ye have? There are days wi you, as wi other folk, I suppose, when yo get up and go through the hours,

column2: just longing for a bit of a change—a bit of a fillip, as it were.
column3: just longing for a bit of a change-a bit of a fillip, as it were.

column2: I know I ha gone and bought a four-pounder out o another bakers shop to common on such days, just because I sickened at the thought of going on for ever wi the same sight in my eyes,
column3: I know I ha gone and bought a four-pounder out o another bakers shop to common on such days, just because I sickened at the thought of going on for ever wi the same sight in my eyes,

column2: and the same sound in my ears, and the same taste i my mouth, and the same thought (or no thought, for that matter) in my head, day after day, for ever.
column3: and the same sound in my ears, and the same taste i my mouth, and the same thought or no thought, for that matter in my head, day after day, for ever.

column2: Ive longed for to be a man to go spreeing, even it were only a tramp to some new place in search o work.
column3: Ive longed for to be a man to go spreeing, even it were only a tramp to some new place in search o work.

column2: And father—all men—have it stronger inthem than me to get tired o sameness and work for ever.
column3: And father-all men-have it stronger inthem than me to get tired o sameness and work for ever.

column2: And what isthem to do? Its little blame to them if they do go into the gin-shop for to make their blood flow quicker,
column3: And what isthem to do? Its little blame to them if they do go into the gin-shop for to make their blood flow quicker,

column2: and more lively, and see things they never see at no other time—pictures, and looking-glass, and such like.
column3: and more lively, and see things they never see at no other time-pictures, and looking-glass, and such like.

column2: But father never was a drunkard, though maybe, hes got worse for drink, now and then.
column3: But father never was a drunkard, though maybe, hes got worse for drink, now and then.

column2: Only yo see, and now her voice took a mournful, pleading tone, at times o strike theres much to knock a man down, for all they start so hopefully;
column3: Only yo see, and now her voice took a mournful, pleading tone, at times o strike theres much to knock a man down, for all they start so hopefully;

column2: and wheres the comfort to come fro?
column3: and wheres the comfort to come fro?

column2: Hell get angry and mad—they all do—and then they get tired out wi being angry and mad, and maybe ha done things in their passion theyd be glad to forget.
column3: Hell get angry and mad-they all do-and then they get tired out wi being angry and mad, and maybe ha done things in their passion theyd be glad to forget.

column2: Bless yor sweet pitiful face! but yo dunnot know what a strike is yet.
column3: Bless yor sweet pitiful face! but yo dunnot know what a strike is yet.

column2: Come, Bessy, said Margaret, I wont say youre exaggerating, because I dont know enough about it:
column3: Come, Bessy, said Margaret, I wont say youre exaggerating, because I dont know enough about it:

column2: but, perhaps, as youre not well, youre only looking on one side, and there is another and a brighter to be looked to.
column3: but, perhaps, as youre not well, youre only looking on one side, and there is another and a brighter to be looked to.

column2: Its all well enough for yo to say so, who have lived in pleasant green places all your life long, and never known want or care, or wickedness either, for that matter.
column3: Its all well enough for yo to say so, who have lived in pleasant green places all your life long, and never known want or care, or wickedness either, for that matter.

column2: Take care, said Margaret, her cheek flushing, and her eye lightening, how you judge, Bessy.
column3: Take care, said Margaret, her cheek flushing, and her eye lightening, how you judge, Bessy.

column2: I shall go home to my mother, who is so ill—so ill, Bessy, that theres no outlet but death for her out of the prison of her great suffering;
column3: I shall go home to my mother, who is so ill-so ill, Bessy, that theres no outlet but death for her out of the prison of her great suffering;

column2: and yet I must speak cheerfully to my father, who has no notion of her real state, and to whom the knowledge must come gradually.
column3: and yet I must speak cheerfully to my father, who has no notion of her real state, and to whom the knowledge must come gradually.

column2: The only person—the only one who could sympathise with me and help me—whose presence could comfort my mother more than any other earthly thing—is falsely accused—would run the risk of death if he came to see his dying mother.
column3: The only person-the only one who could sympathise with me and help me-whose presence could comfort my mother more than any other earthly thing-is falsely accused-would run the risk of death if he came to see his dying mother.

column2: This I tell you—only you, Bessy. You must not mention it.
column3: This I tell you-only you, Bessy. You must not mention it.

column2: No other person in Milton—hardly any other person in England knows.
column3: No other person in Milton-hardly any other person in England knows.

column2: Have I not care? Do I not know anxiety, though I go about well-dressed, and have food enough?
column3: Have I not care? Do I not know anxiety, though I go about well-dressed, and have food enough?

column2: Oh, Bessy, God is just, and our lots are well portioned out by Him, although none but He knows the bitterness of our souls.
column3: Oh, Bessy, God is just, and our lots are well portioned out by Him, although none but He knows the bitterness of our souls.

column2: I ask your pardon, replied Bessy, humbly. Sometimes, when Ive thought o my life, and the little pleasure Ive had in it,
column3: I ask your pardon, replied Bessy, humbly. Sometimes, when Ive thought o my life, and the little pleasure Ive had in it,

column2: Ive believed that, maybe, I was one of those doomed to die by the falling of a star from heaven;
column3: Ive believed that, maybe, I was one of those doomed to die by the falling of a star from heaven;

column2: And the name of the star is called Wormwood; and the third part of the waters became wormwood; and men died of the waters, because they were made bitter.
column3: And the name of the star is called Wormwood; and the third part of the waters became wormwood; and men died of the waters, because they were made bitter.

column2: One can bear pain and sorrow better if one thinks it has been prophesied long before for one: somehow, then it seems as if my pain was needed for the fulfilment;
column3: One can bear pain and sorrow better if one thinks it has been prophesied long before for one: somehow, then it seems as if my pain was needed for the fulfilment;

column2: otherways it seems all sent for nothing.
